{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3459063,"name":"I ask a whole lot of questions ","username":"Gabe4","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/a183cd/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-12-13T22:56:45.418Z","cooked":"

Hey, I am curious about the best way to do April tag tracking. We have a couple of things kicking around and the limelight docs are confusing would it be better to run photon on a 2 or 2+? What would be best? Thanks for the help.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-12-13T22:58:35.290Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":37,"reads":272,"readers_count":271,"score":239.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":476663,"topic_slug":"limelight-with-photon","display_username":"I ask a whole lot of questions ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64491,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limelight-with-photon/476663/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3459068,"name":"Kevin Hjelstrom","username":"KH987","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kh987/{size}/182255_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-13T23:17:19.764Z","cooked":"

Both of them out of the box can do April tag tracking using both stock current limelight firmware. The 2+ is newer hardware than the 2 so I would recommend going with it. If you want to run photon vision software, you will have to check their documentation to see what hardware is compatible - looks like 2 and 2+ are supported on the quick install page.

Are there specific questions you would like to be answered? I can help point to the right place in the documentation.

Ok my main problem was it was not super clear about how to install limelightlib and overall the docs were not really coder friendly to someone who does coding as a second thing for the team and is mainly electrical and basic control system stuff

Check out this page. Towards the top there is a “usage” section that explains how to get limelightlib into your code. It will lead you to a github page where you can download the code you need. Further down in the page shows how to use the code. There are a couple example projects in the documentation as well in the tutorials section.

docs.limelightvision.io

FRC Programming with Limelight Lib (WPILib Java & C++) | Limelight...

* https://github.com/LimelightVision/limelightlib-wpijava

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-12-14T12:01:32.050Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":158,"readers_count":157,"score":41.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":476663,"topic_slug":"limelight-with-photon","display_username":"I ask a whole lot of questions ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":64491,"username":"Gabe4","name":"I ask a whole lot of questions ","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/a183cd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64491,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limelight-with-photon/476663/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3459259,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-14T15:33:00.498Z","cooked":"
Gabe4:

Is it a in subsystem or in robot.java?

A subsystem gives you a Mutual Exclusion (mutex) to a named resource (the class name). From the WPILib documentation:

the scheduler will never concurrently schedule more than one command that requires a given subsystem. An attempt to schedule a command that requires a subsystem that is already-in-use will either interrupt the currently-running command or be ignored

Generally sensors don’t care how many processes can essentially simultaneously read their values so no mutex is required to read values. Some sensors (and robot devices such as arms, elevators, motors) need state changes (different configurations, etc.) and can have only one process at a time change their state. They need the mutex.

The only thing I can think of for vision processing like LL that could change state and require a mutex administered by subsystem is if you change the pipeline. You wouldn’t want one process changing the pipeline while another process is reading/using a different pipeline. If you only use one pipeline, then a subsystem is not useful.

If you can possibly use more than one pipeline in your robot code, then subsystem can help manage multiple pipelines and command access. It is more likely that a command will not read from the wrong pipeline. Of course ,you could still have logic errors that cause commands to cancel other commands unintendedly and change the pipelines at the wrong time but that’s a different problem (look at command logs to troubleshoot that happening).

I’m sorry this description of subsystem with respect to pipeline usage is a little squishy but’s based on how I often see it used in code. It’s more obvious for a drive subsystem that prevents a drive forward command from running while the drive backward command is running. One of the commands is cancelled to make it impossible to happen.

The logic of setting pipelines and using them usually isn’t coded so clean-cut as you can write stupid code to still get into trouble. Subsystem can be helpful but you still have to pay attention to the LL pipeline state and do your own logic for what commands are legal in what states. You have to make an atomic transaction of setting the desired pipeline and using it in the same command. Few want to think about it and take the trouble and I’m not sure that LL processes pipeline change requests fast enough to be practical. This sounds like a case for having subsystems within subsystems as mentioned in a recent CD post (maybe by @oblarg ?). Command-based does not now have that feature but I vaguely remember them saying if you figure out how to do it then let them know.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-12-14T15:33:00.498Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":146,"readers_count":145,"score":29.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":476663,"topic_slug":"limelight-with-photon","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limelight-with-photon/476663/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3459303,"name":"Kevin Hjelstrom","username":"KH987","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kh987/{size}/182255_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-14T17:38:41.140Z","cooked":"

If you are referring to the library, the entire thing goes into the “robot” folder. For implementing tracking, that can go in many different places. My team put the code into the subsystems and commands that utilize it, not in robot.java.

For example in 2024 we had a “shoot speaker” command that check the limelight for a valid target, then rotated the drive train and angle of shooter based on the location of the target. Any time this command was not being called, the code was not reading the limelight values.

If you havn’t already, check out the WPILIB docs for command based programming. It goes over good practices for organizing your code.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-12-14T18:53:12.891Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":102,"readers_count":101,"score":25.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":476663,"topic_slug":"limelight-with-photon","display_username":"I ask a whole lot of questions ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64491,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limelight-with-photon/476663/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3459365,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-14T20:07:59.869Z","cooked":"

My team’s Robot.java does everything periodic. We have Lists of what to run for each category. I don’t think we registered any tasks for runAllPeriodicTasks this year.

    @Override
    public void robotPeriodic()
    {
        // Update all of the periodic inputs.
        PeriodicIO.readAllPeriodicInputs();
        
        // Runs the Scheduler.
        CommandScheduler.getInstance().run();
        
        // Run periodic tasks
        PeriodicTask.runAllPeriodicTasks();

        // Update all of the periodic outputs.
        PeriodicIO.writeAllPeriodicOutputs();
    }
","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-12-14T20:07:59.869Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":95,"readers_count":94,"score":19.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":476663,"topic_slug":"limelight-with-photon","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":64491,"username":"Gabe4","name":"I ask a whole lot of questions ","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/a183cd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limelight-with-photon/476663/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3460780,"name":"I ask a whole lot of questions ","username":"Gabe4","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/a183cd/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-12-18T14:26:29.524Z","cooked":"

My team wants to go to photon and I want to use the LL 2+ to run it. How would I do that?

Edit: Can you run multiple on one robot?
